answers.author: Matthew McQuillen
answers.text:
Toni, in Ankeny we have been through a long term progression from a paid-on-call department to a career/full-time department.  Currently we are at the stage of a hybrid system where we have full-time mixed with paid-on-call who sign up for part-time shifts to create full engine companies in station.  Our FT's work the typical 24 on, 48 off shifts while or POC/PT can sign up for full 24 hour shifts or just 8 hours at a time.  Call me if you need more detail, it is kind of complicated.

answers.author: Michael Webb
answers.text:
The first question is why is the city considering a change?  Is the department also providing EMS transport services?  If so, it may make sense to look at a full-time, paid EMS service supplemented with a volunteer fire department.  As we all know, most fire calls are of an EMS nature.
A combination paid/volunteer can be tricky, especially in a unionized environment.  Our department went directly from volunteer to paid (with a couple of volunteers from time to time) and is paid from general fund revenues.

answers.author: Jeffrey Stonehill
answers.text:
I have been blessed and cursed to work in each type of system, all volunteer, mixed, and all professional firefighters. I must say that the mixed departments always have management issues associated with the tensions between paid and volunteers both in professionals in command and procedures. Ultimately, I like having a fully paid department but the cost of such is absolutely extreme. To offset these expenses, my paid fire department provides BLS ambulance service and acts as our fire inspectors (100% employees certified as EMT and inspectors). Those functions bring in considerable revenue.

answers.author: Christopher Lawrence
answers.text:
Vinton, Virginia has a hybrid system between two career agencies (Town of Vinton and Roanoke County) and a Volunteer Fire Department and a Volunteer First Aid Crew.  It works pretty well.  Solid leadership and committment to provide the service.  It has its moments when things change.  Our Fire is Career staff from 6am-6pm M-F.  Volunteer fire does 6PM-6AM and all weekends and holidays.  EMS is 24 hour-365 career and supported by volunteers who staff a duty crew basically every night.  It works but does require a good amount of communication.
